title.narrative: Giving for Change 2021

description.narrative: - International NGOs - Funders (bilateral, public and private) - Research institutes and universities

The aim of Giving for Change is to foster local giving as an expression of voice, civic participation, solidarity and dissent. The programme will build evidence around new thinking, approaches and leadership that support community philanthropy development.

To influence and partner with international development actors to appreciate, support and promote the development of community philanthropy as a central pillar of broader efforts to shift power and resources closer to the ground, to strengthen local ownership of development processes and to amplify the ability of citizens and communities to be heard and to claim rights and entitlements.
Specific objectives include: - Build on, engage and collaborate with other sector-based initiatives aimed at addressing long-term systemic reform of the international development system. - Grow the visibility, voice and influencing power of southern civil society actors and leaders in the #ShiftThePower movement so that they can participate more fully and have greater voice in conversations and processes aimed at reforming aid. - Promote and foster new ways of working that leverage actors and assets on both emergent (community philanthropy, #ShiftThePower) and mainstream (funders and INGOs) sides of the system.

title.narrative: D3.b International donors support community philanthropy as a strategy for increasing the political dimension of CSA work from a base of increased ownership and legitimacy

description.narrative: In the third domain we aim to challenge and change the existing practices of international foundations, INGOs and bi- and multilateral donors working with southern civil society organizations. We advocate to put community philanthropy at the heart of their funding policy and to focus (more) on brokering, diplomacy and technical expertise roles. This objective was primarily met through the publication of blogs and other thought pieces in mainstream spaces, that make the case for community philanthropy and the broader #ShiftThePower agenda.

comment.narrative: At the beginning of the Giving for Change programme, the baseline was 0.

In 2021, GFCF staff contributed 7 articles and thought pieces to mainstream development and philanthropy spaces, including: - Building Local Giving is Central to Shifting Power - The winner takes it all - Trust is the Currency of Life - and the Accelerator for Community-led Change - The Birth of #ShiftThePower: A Confluence of Forces - 25 Years of Philanthropy - Mapping for the Shifting of Power: A System Change Approach - Reflections and Lessons Learned from the #ShiftThePower Movement We also published 17 articles and blogs written by practitioners on our website, which were disseminated widely via our E-Bulletin and social media channels. In some cases, these were then reposted on other mainstream sites. This included: - Women who don’t stay home - The power of practitioner led research - Turning the world upside down - Power of the tongue: Language and its place in development - Reinforcing the centrality of social movements - Community weaving and the circular economy - The work of a weaver - What do fair trade and community philanthropy have in common - The localization agenda: How successful is it? - Pathways to effectively operationalize localization - Locally-led development - #ShiftThePower and Me - #ShiftThePower and Us: Reconstruction Women’s Fund - A visual journey to #ShiftThePower from Dalia Association - The road travelled and the road ahead - Time to rethink capacity in the Global South - My mother the donor

We foresee 125 contributions (in the form of blogs, articles, though pieces etc.) to mainstream spaces that make the case for community philanthropy and #ShiftThePower over the course of the Giving for Change programme.

comment.narrative: At the beginning of the Giving for Change programme, the baseline was 0.

In 2021, the GFCF contributed to 2 high level processes that illustrated funders' increased interest in the community philanthropy field, including: - GFCF staff and partners contributed to thinking/discussions behind BOND report "Catalysing Locally-Led Development in the UK Aid System." - GFCF co-organized two online sessions in advance of the UN General Assembly, hosted by hosted by ODI in partnership with the 17 Rooms initiative, SHOFCO and Sharing Strategies. The sessions looked at "advocating together for localization, locally and community-led development and shifting power." Additionally, over the year we were in regular contact with 9 government officials, individual donors, emerging philanthropic actor with the aim of influencing practice: - European Commission - Facebook Community Fund - GlobalGiving - NEAR Network - Non-Profit Finance Fund - Open Society Foundations - Save the Children Denmark - START Network - USAID
We foresee 50 cases in which international and bi- or multilateral donors give space to, vocally support, or change funding policy in support of community philanthropy.

title.narrative: D3.i Increased visibility and voice of local national and international networks of community philanthropy

description.narrative: Our particular role is to advocate for community philanthropy and local resource mobilization as part of a reimagined system. We seek to engage a diverse range of stakeholders in dialogues about the role of INGOs and funders in a more equitable and “rightsized” system, as allies of southern civil society that are able to lend specific expertise, to provide opportunities for influence and access in areas of global policy, and as allies in global pushbacks on human rights and the shrinking space.

title.narrative: # of International Foundations and INGOs that have participated in meetings conversations and debates

comment.narrative: At the beginning of the Giving for Change programme, the baseline was 0.

52 representatives of international foundations and INGOs attended GFCF convenings in 2021. The convenings touched on a range of issues highlighting the role of the global community philanthropy field, and included: building local philanthropy during COVID-19; engaging marginalized and minority groups during COVID-19; the #ShiftThePower network map / ecosystem; and, localism, livelihoods and circular economies.

We foresee that 400 international foundations and INGOs will participate in meetings, conversations and debates on #ShiftThePower and community philanthropy over the course of the Giving for Change programme.

D3.g Models tested where top-down vertical structures meet more emergent horizontal ones that allow people to drive their own development.

description.narrative: We are aiming to engage a diverse range of development actors (both funders and INGOs) in testing community philanthropy approaches, to co-create and experiment through pilot projects – whether at the global or country level – in ways that forge new kinds of innovative / power-sharing practices.

title.narrative: # of pilots experiments innovations – practice research and learning – case studies of (I)NGOs/ CSAs testing adopting community philanthropy approaches aimed at strengthening the political roles of CSAs or that demonstrate new ways of community philanthropy practices.

comment.narrative: At the beginning of the Giving for Change programme, the baseline was 0.

In 2021 we were involved in six pilot initiatives/experiments which saw different kinds of funders engaging with community philanthropy/#ShiftThePower in new ways. These included: - Funding from Save the Children Denmark / NEAR Network to test nationally/locally rooted mechanisms which can release funding to local actors efficiently, transparently and flexibly in West Africa and Somalia. - Consultancy with Open Society Foundations Human Rights Initiative around the intersections between local human rights funders and local resource mobilization. - Funding from European Union to support GFCF small grants programme looking at community philanthropy's response to COVID-19 (primarily focusing on Africa). - #ShiftThePower Treehouse launched, with support from Humanity United. - Launch of USAID funded partnership with Non-Profit Finance Fund and GlobalGiving "Assets, Agency and Trust" in the Philippines aimed at strengthening community philanthropy as a strategy to encourage locally-owned development solutions. - Partnership with Complexity University and START Network around 2021 course reimagining humanitarian system from the bottom-up (support to six GFCF teams)
We foresee 25 pilot experiments and new connections/relationships being formed over the course of the Giving for Change programme.

description.narrative: Where funders and INGOs are ready to embark on radically new ways of working and to consider, for example, what supporting a community philanthropy or participatory grantmaking approach might look like in practice, we are seeking to facilitate and accompany new kinds of partnerships, bold experiments, and alliances that harness knowledge and experience and foster co-creation between formal and emergent parts of the system. This is with the belief that these kinds of examples can be picked up, adapted and adopted by others.
